author: markbrus88
title: Arsenal exit would be a big mistake for contract rebel Mesut Ozil
text:
Mesut Ozil could be axed by Arsenal this summer (Picture: Getty) Barely a day goes by without a story that someone is leaving Arsenal in the summer, and the latest is that Arsene Wenger has lost patience with Mesut Ozil to the extent that he’s now ready to let him go .
Wenger himself is by no means certain to still be at the Emirates Stadium next season of course, while Alexis Sanchez is also being strongly tipped to follow both him and Ozil out of the exit door.
Wenger 'furious' with Ozil and ready to sell him after latest slap in the face Still, while Sanchez would undoubtedly find himself a top club (Real Madrid, Paris Saint-Germain and Manchester City are among the many to be linked with him in recent months) – and even Wenger still holds a certain appeal after his superb start to life at Arsenal before working under difficult circumstances in the second half of his reign – it’s harder to make the case for Ozil moving on to bigger and better things.
While the Germany international is undoubtedly a world class playmaker on his day, it’s become all too clear in his four years in England that his day just doesn’t come often enough, or comes mostly in convenient circumstances, such as against the weaker sides or when the rest of the team is also fully clicking; rarely if ever has he taken the game by the scruff of the neck or lifted the rest of the team around him.
Ozil has reportedly angered Wenger by missing the West Brom game (Picture: Getty) Goals + assists 2016/17 Alexis Sanchez 27 Olivier Giroud 11 Theo Walcott 10 Mesut Ozil 9 Share

It’s never easy being a record signing (just ask Paul Pogba), but while the £42.5million Arsenal paid for Ozil in 2013 looked a big statement at the time, it has since been dwarfed by a rapid inflation in transfer fees (David Luiz and John Stones have since moved for more). And while Arsenal are yet to pay more than that for a player, it still seems a fairly modest fee in the modern era.
Damningly for Ozil, that still doesn’t make him look a bargain.
Even with a year left on his contract by the end of this season, one would imagine Ozil would still be a hugely expensive purchase for any club in terms of both transfer fee and wages. Despite being excellent in his three years at Real Madrid, that ship has surely sailed, and apart from that it seems unlikely that any club who could afford him would want him.
Would Ozil really be a better signing than this lot (Picture: Squawka) Ozil’s sluggishness and habit of disappearing when it matters is clear for all to see, but his overall stats have also dropped hugely this season as he’s barely even doing the job asked of him anymore.
He may have finished with 19 assists in the Premier League last season, but he’s slumped to just four so far this year. That might be more forgivable if he made up for it with his goals, but he doesn’t – his return of five this season, combining to an overall goal contribution of nine, just doesn’t scream ‘world class attacking midfielder’.
As the numbers from Squawka above show, if top teams are going to fork out huge sums of cash this summer, it would surely be more wisely spent on the likes of Eden Hazard, Dele Alli, Kevin De Bruyne or Dele Alli – all younger, more consistent and more effective at their jobs.
Ozil hasn’t looked as good since leaving Real Madrid (Picture: Getty) Ozil will turn 29 next season and – last season aside – has not looked a genuinely top ‘number ten’ since he had the luxury of Cristiano Ronaldo to aim at up front; he performs well in a team perfectly set up for him, but there’s little reason for European heavyweights such as Barcelona or Bayern Munich to change the way they play for one flaky and erratic creator.
With his reputation, Ozil may rightly feel he could get himself a gig at a bigger club than Arsenal, but realistically he’s at the stage now where he would only match or better his current wages at a wealthy owner’s glamour project like Paris Saint-Germain or Inter Milan, or even the Chinese Super League. If he’s tempted by a return to Germany, he’s surely not heading to Bayern so would have to make do with a Borussia Dortmund, Schalke or Wolfsburg – none of whom are going to win the Bundesliga and certainly not the Champions League.

Things look bleak at Arsenal right now, but there’s the growing reality that a new manager could be coming in to turn major silverware into a more realistic prospect. Even after recent results, the top four is still in sight, meaning Ozil can continue to play at Europe’s top table next season. Even if Wenger stays, that at least means a team built around Ozil’s strengths, and a club whose philosophy dictates that they’re more willing than others to pin their hopes on Ozil and therefore pay him what he wants.
Wanting to leave Arsenal is hardly controversial at this stage – but Ozil needs to take a look at himself and accept that this is his level now. Leaving would be a cold hard dose of reality for a player who has to take as much blame as anyone for failing to lift his current club up from the level it finds itself in.
